description.narrative: # of women led CSOs with increased L&A capacities.

comment.narrative: Compared to neighbouring Kenya and Uganda, key population community mobilisation in Burundi is limited. Programming for sex workers is the most developed out of all the key populations, though only one sex worker-led organisation is currently functioning, with their development supported by the African Sex Worker Alliance. The community of people who use drugs (PWUD) is primarily organised through the Burundi Association of People who Use Drugs (BAPUD), which has worked to establish effective cooperation with the Burundian police and has ensured that funding for two methadone clinics is included within the Global Fund 2021-2023 country grant. LGBTIQ+ organising is challenged particularly by being French speaking in a region who are English speakers; nevertheless, organizing in this community has growing momentum and has developed and implemented cross-country and regional programs with colleagues in the DRC especially around safety and security and in the movement strengthening pieces of work (Context Analysis, 2020).

1 organisation led by Women groups from communities of Sexual and Gender Minorities, Sex Workers or Persons Who Use Drugs, have increased capacity to advocate for KP rights.This is a target for all the 5 years i.e. 2021 - 2025

Support to strengthen capacities of sex workers organising
Grantee partner which is a female sex worker led organisation, fights against all forms of sex trafficking and seeks to improve sex workers’ living conditions, their mental and physical health. Through UHAI support the grantee partner led capacity building initiatives for her members. They were able to observe COVID-19 prevention measures (Hand washing, wearing masks and social distancing) They were trained on COVID-19 symptoms and equipped with information on testing centres,contributing to reducing COVID-19 virus transmission within their communities. Grantee partner was able to work in close collaboration with LGBTI organisations working in Burundi in some of the HIV/AIDS control programmes, more specifically those run by L’ANSS (the Burundi National Association for support to people living with HIV and AIDS). Grantee partner collaborated with other CSOs (in the drug users project). Together, they have created UBUNTU which is a platform through which they can find solutions to their common challenges. Through strategic partnership with a KP-led organisation in Burundi, this grantee partner was mentored on project management and related technical skills.

2 KP-led organisations in Burundi were supported to build their capacity.
By supporting this grantee partner to engage in a peer learning and exchange process exchange with an established Trans-led organisation that has built its expertise in working on transgender issues, which would allow them to acquire knowledge on how to design programs that speaks to the needs of their constituents in Burundi. Partners developed organisational governance and administrative and leadership skills, as well as advocacy and communication skills. This has ensured that they are able to design programs that speak to the needs that speak to the needs of the Trans community in Burundi.
The grantee partner in Burundi gained knowledge of strategic organizational leadership techniques such as decision making and plan implementation Knowledge of leadership processes such as strategic planning, conflict management and staff development. They now have knowledge of organizational leadership techniques, strategies such as decision making and implementing plans, as well as leadership processes such as strategic planning, communication, conflict management and staff development.
A community of practice (CoP) by organising a group learning workshop for LGBTIQ organisations to share and transfer knowledge, every three months was created.
The COP provided organisations with a culture of collective problem-solving, providing quick solutions and developing knowledge and new skills while decreasing the competitive spirit. It has contributed to the emergence of new practices that their members can test and which will be given back to the collective.

description.narrative: # of by-laws for sustainable and inclusive development that are better implemented as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: Government attention to key populations has grown due to influence by the international and local advocates, and there is enough material and information relayed via both soft and physical training enhancing the awareness levels of key populations needs in Burundi (Context Analysis, 2020). HIV CSO’s have also trained an array of stakeholders from different sectors on key populations, thus creating an informed and skilled workforce. LGBTIQ+ CSO’s have also engaged in SRHR conversations and with these efforts, information is available online and via other mediums (Context Analysis, 2020).
4 by -laws for sustainable and inclusive development that are better implemented as a result of CSO engagement. This is a target for all the 5 years i.e. 2021 - 2025

UHAI supported 2 grantee organisations in Burundi to attend ICASA in Durban, South Africa. This meeting was very strategic as immediately after a member of UHAI’s grantee partner organisation was nominated to be a representative of KPS on PEPFAR.
As follow-up actions in support of our activists, UHAI linked them with Health Gap as support to the KP representative on engagement with PEPFAR in Burundi.
ICASA 2021 was a space where UHAI's grantees meaningfully participated in finding resource tailored interventions for communities of Sexual and Gender Minorities, Persons Who Use Drugs and Sex Workers - as one of the most affected populations with regards to the HIV/AIDS epidemic.
